title: 103_s1899
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is listed on the National Historic Register and designated as a significant resource. It features excellent water quality, historic landscapes, mill structures, and recreational opportunities. The area connects to national historic districts and landmarks, offering scenic vistas and undeveloped spaces for visitors. The Augusta Canal area, connected by the Augusta Canal, offers beautiful rural landscapes, historic cultural sites, and recreational opportunities. It represents the development of the cotton textile industry in the South and holds significant sites related to American history. Despite efforts by various organizations, the area remains undeveloped. The Augusta Canal area, encompassing Revolution, the Civil War, and various American ethnic groups, is at risk of losing its cultural, historical, and natural resources without federal assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has identified it as a priority for protection, and there is strong local support for collaborative efforts to preserve and enhance the Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Act also defines the boundaries of the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area. Establishment of Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in Georgia and South Carolina, as outlined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan of 1993. Boundaries to be detailed by the Secretary of the Interior. Creation of Augusta Canal Commission. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary from various recommendations. The Commission will elect a chairman from its members, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of this Act's enactment. The plan should integrate existing Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, for the protection and enhancement of cultural, natural, and recreational resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance, and must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days based on specific criteria. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan for the Heritage Area within 180 days based on specific criteria, including local support, economic impact, partnership potential, property rights, and observance. The management plan for the Heritage Area must be approved or disapproved by the Secretary within 180 days based on criteria including local support, economic impact, partnership potential, and property rights observance. If disapproved, the Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the plan with recommendations for revision. The Commission must continue to revise and resubmit the plan until approved by the Secretary. Upon receipt of the revised plan, the Secretary will approve or disapprove it. The Augusta Canal Commission will revise and resubmit the plan until approved. Upon approval, the Secretary will work with the Commission to implement the plan through cooperative agreements. Economic development efforts will be encouraged by the Augusta Commission, the State of Georgia, and local entities to align with the Augusta Canal Master Plan goals. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's establishment. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
